label: thm-mean-field-equation
title: The Mean-Field Equations for the Euclidean Gas
nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system describing the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$, comprising a PDE for $f$ and an ODE for $m_d$.

equations.label: eq-mean-field-pde-main
equations.latex: \partial_t f = L^\dagger f - c(z)f + B[f, m_d] + S[f]

\partial_t f(t,z) = -
abla\cdot(A(z) f(t,z)) + 
abla\cdot(\mathsf{D}
abla f(t,z)) - c(z)f(t,z) + \lambda_{	ext{revive}} m_d(t)  rac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} + S[f](t,z)

hypotheses.text: Initial condition for the alive density: $f(0, \cdot) = f_0$
Initial condition for the dead mass: $m_d(0) = 1 - \int_{\Omega} f_0$

conclusion.text: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by the coupled system defined by the PDE for the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the ODE for the dead mass $m_d(t)$.

constraints: zero in interior, positive near boundary

label: thm-mass-conservation
title: Total Mass Conservation and Population Dynamics
nl_statement: Any sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations conserves total population mass and has an evolution for the alive mass governed by the balance between killing and revival.

hypotheses.text: $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ is a sufficiently regular solution to the Mean-Field Equations.

conclusion.text: The total population mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t)$ is conserved for all $t>0$, and the alive mass $m_a(t)$ evolves according to $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}m_a(t) = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_d(t) - k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The total mass $m_a(0) + m_d(0) = 1$ if the conservation result holds for all $t$.

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under specified regularity assumptions, a smooth killing rate function $c$ exists, leading to pointwise convergence of the discrete exit rate to $c$ (Part i), and uniform convergence of the expected killing fraction rate to the continuous killing rate, with an explicit error bound (Part ii).

hypotheses.text: Density regularity assumptions hold for killing

conclusion.text: There exists a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ with compact support in $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ such that Part (i) (pointwise convergence of exit rate) and Part (ii) (uniform convergence of expected killing fraction) hold.
conclusion.latex: \exists c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega) \text{ s.t. Part (i) and Part (ii) hold}

variables.role: outward unit normal vector at x

implicit_assumptions.text: The domain $\Omega$ is non-empty and has a boundary.
The notion of 'valid states' $X_{\text{valid}}$ is well-defined.
The definition of $d(x)$ (distance to boundary) is standard.
The notation $f^\tau$ represents the density evolved by the discrete flow/integrator.

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: If the empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, x, v)$ of the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to $f(t, x, v)$ in the joint limit $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ under the condition $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: Let $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ be the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics with timestep $\tau$.
The limit is taken as $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

conclusion.text: The empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, \cdot, \cdot)$ converges weakly to $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The system being considered is the Fragile Gas dynamics.
Weak convergence refers to convergence in the sense of distributions/measures.
